txt.en: 'Speak again only when you have all slept, and when mead no longer heats your hearts.'
'Fram, take the dragon's-tooth necklace, and send it to Erebor instead of the treasures.'
'Had the dwarves not enough new riches from the lodes they had already discovered beneath the Lonely Mountain?'
'Were the riches of Gundabad not already laden with too many ill memories amongst their people?'
Instance: The Ill-fated Feast
'Had the Thíuda not given them shelter in their darkest years, after the fall of Khazad-dûm, and were they not owed tribute in return?'
'Matters took an untoward turn when Fram revealed the prizes he had brought forth from Scatha's lair.'
'The Longbeard herald recognized the treasures as heirlooms of his people.'
'Fram blew a note upon the silver horn to begin the feast.'
'Fram saw otherwise.'
'I agree.'
'Perhaps the request was ill-timed, while he still mourned the father he had lost to the Worm's bite.'
'Behold these prized treasures from Scatha's hoard!'
'Yes, share the wealth, Fram.'
'Perhaps he was afflicted by dragon-sickness from the hoard itself.'
'Let the feast begin!'
'Perhaps some other dark thoughts weighed upon him.'
'Regardless, he was wroth at the dwarves' request, and rebuked them for it.'
'You may not lay claim to any of Scatha's hoard.'
'Discussions grew heated, and might have come to blows but for the counsel of Wandalb Greyhame, who had come to attend the feast out of curiosity.'
'These treasures belong solely to my people, dwarf!'
'I do not care what Thráin thinks! He did not even come to my hall!'
'I thank you for your advisement. I agree with some of which you speak, Wandalb.'
'Why, that is dwarf treasure. I know dwarf-craft when I see it!'
'Hold a moment, Fram! How can you lay sole claim to stolen dwarf treasures?!'
'Surely, since dwarf-hands had wrought them, you would see this?'
'They had been plundered from dwarf-halls either by the dragon itself or by those it had devoured before!'
'Some share of the wealth must belong to Durin's Folk?'
'Now look here, Man! Do you not care about the wishes of Thráin?!'
'Why you disrespecting, no good...'
The following day Wandalb advised a compromise.
'The Wizard stayed hands that had strayed to sword-hilt and axe-haft, but when he prevailed upon Fram to see reason the lord refused to be moved.'
'Enough, my friends. We come here for food and drink, not bloodshed.'
'Fram, perhaps you and your guests should retire for the night.'
'A reasonable request.'
